Q2:
Before we go further, we will first define a few terms. 

 


	Genetic modification is the process of altering an organism’s genome (its full set of genes) by inserting genes from one organism into another. 
	Gene editing is the process of using a tool that works like a pair of scissors to make edits in an organism’s genes—unlike genetic modification, these edits are targeted to a specific location in the organism’s genome.
	Gene drives are a technique that ensures that an edit is inherited by the next generation and eventually spreads through that organism’s population. 





Based on these definitions, would you say that these three processes—genetic modification, gene editing, and gene drives—seem similar to each other, or different from each other?

Q16A:
Next, we’d like to ask you a couple questions about some tradeoffs involving gene-edited crops.

 

First, some researchers think that growing gene-edited crops could be used to significantly reduce the volume of pesticides used on farms. This is because those crops would be edited to be resistant to specific pests, and so farms could avoid general spraying.



 

Assuming scientists are right about this, which of the following choices between production of gene-edited crops and pesticide use do you prefer?
Q17A: Please feel free to add any comments that you had on this question about tradeoffs between gene-edited crops and pesticide use:
Q18A:
Some researchers also think that use of gene-edited crops could benefit the conservation of biodiversity. This is because edited versions might have higher crop yields per area of land than non-edited ones. Therefore, less land (e.g., forest habitat) would be converted to agriculture.



 

Assuming scientists are right about this, which of the following choices between gene-edited crop production and biodiversity do you prefer?

Q3: sounds like in genetic modification you are altering by inserting from one organism into another. gene editing doesn't say whether or not it is from the same organism or another...just that it is a specific location in the organism's genome. Ditto for "seedless" watermelons which irks me more than anything. So we now find only "seedless" watermelons in grocery stores now because someone clown thinks that it's an inconvenience to have to find seeds in our fruit. A fruit is basically an ovary. It's supposed to have seeds! There is nothing wrong with that! Incidentally, only in North America do I find this be true. When I travel to Europe or the Caribbean, I get the real thing--not some fake imitation. Why we as a society "need" the convenience of "seedless" fruit (which it never really is; the seeds are just white) is beyond me.

And God forbid and anesthetic be used as that, too, would "cost too much". After all, it's just an animal (who has no rights), right? NOTE: I am a male meat eater. Q3:
They all involve altering DNA but are very specific and differing operations performed on DNA.
A crude analogy:  Measuring a piece of wood.
                           Cutting a piece of wood.
                           Nailing a piece of wood.
The above is all being done on a piece of wood but different tools are used and different physical actions taken to do each thing in respect to the piece of wood.

Q3:
With GM you could take an apple and insert the genes of a plum, getting a fruit that was shaped like an apple, was the colour and consistency of a plum and had seeds like an apple.  Thereby making a totally different fruit if you then did GD to make the changes continue through the generations
With GE you could insert a gene that changed the colour of the apple but everything else remained the same. Again you would have to then do GD to ensure that the change continued through the following generations.
With GD this would mean that the changes from the GE modification would continue on from generation to generation.
Q5: I am generally uncomfortable with the idea of GMO.  I do see that there can be benefits.  For example making a crop drought resistant or resistant to certain diseases that can decimate crops. They could start breast feeding at puberty and if we did the GM right they could continue on well beyond menopause.  Just a thought.  Run it by the dairy cows and see what they think.

Q9:
The rationale "As these horns can injure other cows as well as the farmers or workers that handle dairy cattle" initially sounds laudable; the question begs to be asked: 
If dairy cows injuring other cows (and handlers) is so serious an issue; perhaps there R other more serious aspects of the conditions they are kept in that need to be addressed, e.g. are they confined inside too much (not enough pasture time, too little space in the barns, being constantly artificially impregnated, having offspring removed ASA it's born and shipped off to be slaughtered f. veal, etc., etc.)....
Q11:
Cows (and ALL living beings) need to be treated as ethically & humanely as possible; they shud NOT simply be viewed as flesh & blood milk (or meat) producing machines!
As a devout Christian, I feel we humans (ironically incl. many so-called "fundamentalist Christians") need to treat ALL of God's creation w. respect; having dominion over nature's creatures does NOT mean carte blanche f. unbridled exploitation of said nature, but,  milking needs to be less often and less strenuous, dairy cows shud be allowed to at least raise every other calf; held under less stressful, cramped conditions, etc., etc.
More research & funds shud be invested into finding win-win solutions to improve the well-being of the cows AND their economic utility; it shud not be viewed as a trade-off! (my two cents worth  ;)
Q13:
The overwhelming scale of the benefits of making more wheat available for vast undernourished/starving populations in various parts of the world by averting/reducing loss of wheat crops to prolonged drought overrides my ethical objections to man's interference in nature!
Of course, it is only acceptable if this is done primarily in those regions most under threat of food/wheat shortages around the world!

in gene modification entire genome of an organism is modified, so the organism might behave completely differently than it's original. 
in gene editing, only a specified behavior is targeted, so the organism will behave close to its original.
in gene drive, its enforced to propagate the modified / edited gene in successive generations so that it become part of that organisms

Q3: They are similar in that they are all dealing with the genes.  But they are different in that it seems to be a 1-2-3 process.  The only way I can explain it - is when they create 1 type of apple from two other types.  They take parts of one and parts of the other and that is the "modification".  Now this new apple has grown and they now take it and make an edit to let's say make is more resistant to an apple disease = editing. Then when they are happy with the results one last change is done so when this new apple grows on trees these changes will be continued in the next generations = gene drives.
Q5: Oh Please do it!! Do it now!!  When I was a child and into my teens I lived in a house with a huge vegetable garden.  We grew our own carrots, beans, and a whole bunch of other stuff including a number of different tomatoes,  Biting into one of those tomatoes right off the vine - omg - heaven on earth - the taste, the texture, the smell - complete heaven on earth.  Then you go to the grocery store and pick one up there.  The look is similar but that is where it ends. Almost tasteless, no smell.  This childhood of mine was over 50 years ago and I have not had access to a garden since then.  I am stuck with these tasteless, smell-less tomato wanna-be.  So if someone goofed all those years ago when they gm'd the tomatoes the first time and removed the taste and the sweetness - then I think it is way past time that that mistake was recitified.  Please do it before I leave this earth.  I would love to taste a proper tomato once more.
Q7: I'm not familiar with sugar beets so I don't feel I can make a reasonable comment on that.  If I understand what you're asking - you want to use the sweetness gene from a sugar beet and put that into a tomato?  Are they compatible?  Wouldn't that make the tomato just sweet?  What about the missing flavor from the tomatoes of today?  It was flavor and sweetness that was lost.  Sweet alone won't cut it.  You need the proper flavor back to make it a proper tomato again.  For this one I am going to have to go with Don't know/not sure.  I need more information.
Q9: Considering the horns are removed surgically and it causes pain & suffering to the cattle, it would make sense to gm them.  No more pain and suffering for the cattle. On a side note - it seems the elephants are doing the same thing on their own with the tusks. The elephants are not growing them anymore. But that is evolution not gm.  No tusks = no poachers killing them.
Q11: The first thing I would have to ask is WHY?  What would be the purpose of increasing the producing capacity of the cows.  If I could be provided with a really good reason - like stopping the surgical horn removal - then I might say ok.  Right at this moment I haven't been given a reason so I will have to state that I Don't know/not sure.
Q13: I know alot of people are against genetically modified anything.  But we humans have modified our world - in a bad way - so the science people have to modify our food products to allow them to thrive in a world that was never meant to be like this.  Basically I feel quit mucking around with the world and nobody will gm the food.  But if you want to eat - food has to grow - world is changing so the food has to change to thrive.
Q15: See previous answer regarding the wheat.  Wheat or blueberries - a crop is a crop.
Q16A: Don't know/not sure
Q17A: The way we humans have mucked up this beautiful world is a crying shame.  But because we have mucked it up I know that we have to do something with the crops in order to keep eating. I know as a child with our family back-yard garden we did use pesticides to keep the bugs away and to get rid of the ones that we had.  Pesticides are not good for you.  Everyone knows that. Will gene-edited food affect the human bodly? We don't know?  Right off the bat I would have gone with the first choice of increased production and decreased pesticides.  But then I get to the bottom of the question and I get two other options which have me scratching my head. Is there another way to avoid pesticide use?  And then the real kicker - about who owns or controls these technologies.  I'm sorry to say that once again I'm going to have to go with Don't know/not sure.
Q18A: Don't know/not sure
Q19A: The basic facts are that humans are a greedy, self-serving, selfish species.  Oh don't get me wrong there are some good ones out there that are trying very hard to preserve forests and biodiversity.  But you know as well as I do that huge amounts of wildlife habitats are lost every day to human agriculture.  So let's say we pick number one - increase of production of ge crops in exchange for large improvements to biodiversity.  Do you honestly think that a greedy corporation would go for that?  Now just pulling numbers here out of a hat.  With wheat - an acre of wheat (regular not gm'd) might feed what 10 people. But gm the wheat and that same acre might feed 1,000.  Now you want those corporations to stay on that one little acre of land.  They will say no way we will expand - and to hell with the wildlife and such like. If we can feed 1,000 people from 1 acre think what we can do with a million acres.  I would love to answer the first choice but my believe in human kindness concerning animal welfare is a little on the low side.  So I will once again say Don't know/not sure.  But I would hope and pray that one day it would be treating this world and the other species that share it with us with respect.

Q3: I think they are mostly used as means to very similar ends (they are all used in the realm of changing phenotypical expressions), but at the same time would require quite different procedures with some key differences in purpose. Genetic modification requires the knowledge and presence of a complete gene to splice into a genome, introducing a particular trait that isn't there, while editing seems more useful for "fixing" something that seems like a problem (while the gene that is there is quite similar to the target structure). I suppose gene drives can be used in either case, but represents an intention to modify a population as opposed to an individual organism.
Q5: This goes to far in the direction of Frankenstein. And it is reminiscent of the problem of hydrogenating fats. I would rather grow the heirloom tomatoes and deal with them being lumpy — is it really that big an issue? I doubt it. $$$$
Q7: See reasoning in previous question.
Q9: I wonder how hornless dairy cattle would feel when looking around at the majority with horns. I also wonder if the horned dairy cattle would take advantage of the hornless ones. I would rather energy and effort be spent on discovering and creating environmental conditions that would lessen the probability of harm to humans and cattle and to provide human and effective tools for dealing with harm when it occurs. This seems far less invasive.
Q11: This is like a no win situation for dairy cattle. They have to be milked more, which I would imagine is kind of exhausting and painful, or they will be exhausted and in pain from excess milk in their glands. I almost need to cry at the notion.
Q13: You never know the long term effects of introducing a foreign species into an ecosystem and I think the same applies to the modification of an existing species (because it makes the organism quite a different kind of competitor). Same token, we've been doing ish-similar stuff with selective breeding for a long time, which doesn't seem to have devastated ecosystems. Hard to say if the relative rapidity of the lab approach makes a difference there. I would hope that people are asking themselves to what degree the change is necessary. I doubt this happens (with a perspective that seesfurther than the width of dollar bills).
Q15: Same reasoning. The importance of the crop is involved in the question of necessity.

Q3: They run the gamut from full, multiple gene replacement, to replacing only a partial portion of a gene(s) to ensuring that the first 2 above persist to new generations (using gene drive). All significantly different purposes and results.....
Q5: There is no reason the market tomatoes should not taste better for public consumption.  However, I like heirloom tomatoes. too - look / shape and taste!
Q7: No reason to use a sugar beet which is a different species then tomatoes! Also, there is an increased possibility of ending up with an error or mistake in mixing the two. This would be a boundary I would not want crossed.
Q9: The horns are a defense mechanism.  I think cows are not inherently aggressive unless they have need to be.  Assuming the possibility that humans could die out and disappear (WW3, an incurable deadly virus with many mutations-a "Covid-19?-), these animals would likely die out due to being unable to defend themselves against predators (wolfs, wild dogs, whatever.)
Q11: Milk consumption is going steadily down as the public wants more almond milk or other substitutes. A number of milk companies have already gone out of business.  If you increase milk supply (without reducing dairy herds), you end up with the same situations that oil is currently in-a glut with crashing prices and not economically working.
Q13: The basic wheat is virtually the same except with a tad more "survivor value" in terms of being more resistant to temperature rise and water decrease.
Q15: There is no real intrinsic change in the blueberry-texture, taste, nutrients, etc.  It is like putting a life jacket on someone who cannot swim-no big deal.  He / she can now be able to stay afloat and swim / move around with people who swim w/o any aid....

Q17A: On surface, it looks a very interesting proposal to increase production of crop while decreasing the pesticides used. However, what is unknown in this case is what other effects (harmful or not) of the gene editing will be caused by this choice. The proposal should be put in balance in order to see the positive effects of this proposal on one side versus the negative and harmful effects (if any) to the consumer on the other side. So the jury is out due to the lack of information.
Q18A: A large increase in production of gene-edited crops in exchange for large improvements to biodiversity
Q19A: Again, on surface, it looks a very interesting proposal to increase production of crop while increasing the improvement to biodiversity. However, what is unknown in this case is what other effects (harmful or not) of the gene editing will be caused by this choice. The proposal should be put in balance in order to see the positive effects of this proposal on one side versus the negative and harmful effects (if any) to the consumer on the other side. So in a way the jury is out due to the lack of information.

Gene modification is totally changing the makeup of a organism gene inserting a gene from a different composition.
Gene editing is targeting a specific area of an organism to have a different composition. 
Gene drives is ensuring that either one of the above processes worked and that new organisms are growing based on the genetic changes.

Q3: They are all techniques related to changing an organism's genome. It seems as if you could possibly edit an individual's gene(s) without using a gene driver. Also seems as if genetic modification could insert additional genes rather than replace individual gene(s) by gene editing.

Q3:
Modification is adding something that doesn't belong - like a fish gene in a plant.
Editing would be removing an undesirable characteristic, while leaving everything else the same.  Or, it might facilitate more of an existing desirable trait to blossom or dominate.
Drives would prevent one having to make the modification each and every time one wanted to have a result - e.g., mules are very useful but they can't reproduce themselves so creating them is too much work and takes too much time.
Q5:
It's actually a step "backwards" towards the original.   
Commercial tomatoes are more of a "franken-tomato" than the proposed edited one - an unnatural shape and unnatural sweetness and flavour.   The edited one would only have one "deviation"
Q7:
I am uncomfortable with this approach NOT because I feel afraid of "attack of the killer tomatoes".
I would fear dollars dictating that only tomatoes anyone would grow commercially would be the super-sweet beet-gened ones since we simply can't be obese enough.   So it depends on what is done with the old genetics and with tomatoes that taste like tomatoes and not sugared fruit.
Q9: The only downside I can see is an inevitable loss of the original genetics - the creation of a mono-culture - because  the "need" to do it is dollars.  Saving the animals from the pain of surgery is how we rationalize and justify it after the fact but it's not the real reason.    Whenever man goes whole-hog into mono-culture, the benefits are usually short term with problems later.    When human civilization collapses and dairy cattle are no longer kept safe and fed in fenced fields and barns,they won't be able to defend themselves without horns and will get wiped out.   We need to keep some herds with original genomes around, just in case.
Q11: Assuming this meant taking a cow gene from one variety and inserting it into another to create a third variety - e.g. taking a Guernsey gene and putting it into a Holstein to get a Holstein's daily production with a Guernsey's butter fat levels.  Seems worthwhile as long as feed conversion improves too.  By that I mean, if 2 Guernseys produced the same amount of profit as one Holstein, I'd rather have the two Guernseys to deal with than one giant Holstein.
Q13:
If the author of the question didn't have his own doubt about doing this, he would have named the other plant species and explained what the spliced gene did. 
Anytime something is not clearly and thoroughly labelled, I know someone is trying to hide something from me and, therefore, I oppose it on principle.
Q15:
Commercial importance is NOT the issue.
We are putting the stuff into our bodies.  There is NO difference that can be justified by "importance".  A very specious argument.
Again I say, anytime something is not clearly and thoroughly labelled, I know someone is trying to hide something from me and, therefore, I oppose it on principle.
Q16A: I prefer not to answer this question because it doesn't discuss other ways of avoiding pesticide use
Q17A:
Again it's about money and not what we put into our bodies.  If a plant is resistant to pests it is because it produces "natural" poisons.  If they can harm pests, they can harm me.   Without knowing what the poison produced by the plants is, I can't assess whether it's worse to eat plants with built in poisons (which can't be washed off) - vs - plants that have mad-made poisons sprayed on.  Just because a poison isn't "natural" doesn't preclude it from being less harmful than "natural" poisons.   
I don't care who owns technology if it's good technology that doesn't harm me.  If they can give me safe food I'm glad they can make money too.   But when they can't or won't  fully label and disclose, I have to say again - anytime something is not clearly and thoroughly labelled, I know someone is trying to hide something from me and, therefore, I oppose it on principle.
Q18A: A large increase in production of gene-edited crops in exchange for large improvements to biodiversity
Q19A:
I can only answer in this way if all other issues are properly and ethically dealt with - i.e. proper, independent study and verification, full comprehensive and transparent labelling.
Don't try a misdirection play to get me to lower my guard vis-a-vis full disclosure on what goes into my body.

Q3: All of these have the potential for creating unwanted, or potentially dangerous or harmful mutations in an existing genome. The context of "editing" versus modification, only appears to be slightly different in that it does not specify if the changes are the result of material from an external organism. That is, by this definition an edit could be a removal of, or some other alteration of the genetic sequence without introduction of foreign material, but it also does not preclude foreign DNA, just that it is "targeted" toward a specific result. The context of the gene drive is a logical extension of either technique, since propagation of the desired trait or mutation is the reason to make the alteration in the first place - that is, to insure that the changes create offspring with the desired trait. To the extent that these offspring supplant and replace an entire population-rather than resulting in a distinct new species with the desired trait, makes this a rather radical idea.
Q5: I am not sure of the logic or value of the process. If the supermarket tomato has been selectively bred for cosmetic reasons but taste is lacking, then it is a matter for the consumer to determine if the "heirloom" tomato's superior flavor is worth the "ugliness". If however other characteristics were what was selected for in creation of the "supermarket" tomato, then the flavor profile ought to be achievable by further selective breeding instead of "scissors".
Q7: This goes back to my original premise. If you add genes from a different species - in fact a different genus, you are creating something that is no longer a tomato. It is a new thing that has not existed, has not evolved, and could potentially be harmful, or, if propagated to future crops, mutate into something harmful.
Q9: This entire premise is fallacious. Beef cattle do in fact have horns. Most beef grown here in Texas are from Angus, Brahma, or Longhorn variety of the cow, all of which have prominent horns. Horns are part of the genetic heritage of the bovine group, and this is reflected in their wild relations such as buffalo, bison, wildabeast, and muskox. In any case, I am not motivated by the fact that a long standing and effective procedure to remove the horns is creating "pain and suffering" anymore than an automated milking machine is.
Q11: I don't feel that genetic manipulation beyond selective breeding is EVER a good idea, because I don't believe our scientific understanding of potentially harmful side effects is sufficient to do it. Let's suppose that this is done. For 50 or 100 years we get good milk producing cattle, then some mutation occurs in the environment which results in a virus wiping out these wonder-cows because the genetic change destroyed an innate immunity. And in 50 or 100 years all the pre-wonder-cows have died off because they weren't commercially viable, so now we have no cows at all. This is the problem I have with the entire context of genetic manipulation.
Q13: I am a great supporter of selectively breeding for hardier crops, crops that fair better in certain soils, climates, or other ecosystemic considerations. However, the introduction of new genetic material from something that is not wheat means that the resulting organism IS NOT wheat. While such a forced alteration may be benign, it is equally possible that it can be a lethal issue in the long term. Wheat, even though it has been selectively bred for several thousand years, is the result of long natural evolution along with our species. Introducing a non-natural change in that genetic structure has the potential to cause problems with our species since we did not evolve with that genetic structure.
Q15: The reasoning is the same as before. Creating something which did not evolve naturally or come about by selective breeding creates a product which is not genetically harmonious with the species that is consuming it. While it can be tested in the near term, it is difficult, if not impossible, to evaluate the long term effects because a direct causal link may not appear for decades or longer.
Q16A: I prefer not to answer this question because it doesn't discuss other ways of avoiding pesticide use
Q17A: I believe that the increase in pesticide use is related to many factors, including profitability, corporate farming models, and the reduction in natural predation of pest due to the predators being wiped out by pesticides. The pests eat the crops for the same reason people do. If you grow a plant that the bug doesn't want to eat, you may find the human can't eat it either.
Q18A: I prefer not to answer this question because it doesn't discuss other ways of conserving biodiversity
Q19A: To argue for the need for biodiversity while at the same time creating artificial species is extremely fallacious. Biodiversity is the natural outcome of long-term evolutionary adaptation. Agriculturally produced domestic species already threaten such adaptation. To create something that has not come about from that environment because it "might" mean smaller amounts of the environment be given over to agriculture seems poorly considered.

Q3: Genetic modification is simply adding a gene or genes from another organism. Gene editing is removing a gene or part of a gene. Gene drives are simply confirming that modifications or edits have been integrated into a new standard for the organism's genetic makeup. All involve the genetic makeup of an organism but there are minor differences in the focus of each.

Q7: Again - I now know a sugar beet was used, as opposed to a plant I've never heard about.  The idea of using an identified, natural plant gene to improve another plant is fascinating.
Q9: While I understand the logic and need for the process, I dislike the thought of altering animals.  While I'd rather know they are altered instead of suffering through surgery,  I see both good and bad sides to the process.  The editing could eventually make dairy cattle easier to breed and farm, but what if a 'bad' gene is used?  How would that affect the cattle population?
Q11: I see both positive and negative aspects.  Yes - cows will produce more milk which will feed the population of the world and generate income for farmers and dairy manufacturing.  I also want to know the animal rights are going to be protected and they will not be over-producing milk for profit.  Will there be guarantees in place to protect the animals?

Q19B: The concept is clear but no mention was made of what else might be done with the land.  The explanation mentions forest habitat, but in this area, there are buildings going up everywhere.  This used to be a suburban area and now it's becoming urban.  The idea of gene-editing to produce higher crop yield makes sense, but only if the land is truly protected from other development and remains in its natural state.

Q3:
The each present a different goal, gene modification is a change that takes on the entire genome of the organism, almost like a new species.
Gene editing keeps most of the attributes of the species, however, it focuses on one attribute. To either, enhance it, or to ensure its destruction, like pest control, or weed control, or human control.
Gene drives is a process to ensure the modifications become a permanent feature that is carried forward in species propagation.

He told us in the course that the McDonald Co. used to purchase its potatoes from Idaho farmers who didn't use pesticides because their potatoes were genetically modified. After "Frankenfoods" protests from "activists", the company reverted its stance and the farmers had to go back to pesticide-grown crops. I could not verify if this is a true story, but considering where I got it from, I believed it.
